title: The Evolution of the European Machine Translation Programme at the EPO
segmentation: Yes, also the European Patent Office has a story to tell about machine translation.
How could it be different with so many countries which are Member States?
So let me just start with a very, very quick introduction about the institution.
Maybe most of you know it.
Maybe some of you don't so.
Just.
Couple of bullet points.
First of all, the European Patent Office supports.
Growth in economic growth, competitiveness and innovation across Europe in order to bring indeed.
Welfare through the services which are offered through the patent system user community.
Through the European Patent convention.
So what is maybe peculiar is that the European Patent Office is not or not yet you institution, and it is a self funding institution.
As a matter of fact, which finances itself through the fees which are paid for the services.
Here you have a map which shows the coverage of the Member States of the European Patent Office, which is a bit wider than EU.
As you can see there are few Member States more we have 37 at the moment.
Last one Albania joined on the 1st of May 2010.
So.
Why is the machine translation important for the European Patent Office?
First of all, I have maybe to to make a disclaimer at this point, in the sense that the European Patent Office is such is translating a lot in the sense that we have three working languages.
So there are many internal proceedings which are translated into English, French and German.
However, what I want to address here.
Is the translation of patent documents as such in order either to make them available to large public and this is what is described in the first bullet point.
So access to patent information all across Europe through all patent users.
We also use supporting user machine translation in order to support the London Agreement, which is a bit the first attempt to make the patent system less expensive through translation.

And also we try and it is our intention also through our policy line of course, but especially in the translation issue we support the institution of the Community patterns and very important machine translation should also help the examiners at the PEO, but also at other national patent offices to search the prior art.
So here you have an overview of the historical background, how the machine translation first was introduced to the Patent Office.
There was a decision in 2004 from the Administrative Council, our governing body.
To set to go towards machine translation.
The objective was actually relatively realistic one and and modest one, so it was to make pattern text understandable.
Only understandable to technical experts in the various fields.
Now, as you can imagine, this objective has been completely over run through the new developments.
The expectations have raised a lot.
In the meantime, this is no longer enough for a service to be offered.
However, in 2004 we run a call for tender.
We received offers actually only from providers of a rule based engine.
And the selection went to accompany you are in US Cold War lingo offering a system.
Cistron the particular approach that is probably interesting is that the dictionaries were built on the basis of the IPC, so technical.
The terms were extracted from the patent documents and then aligned according to the IPC code.
Because the same terms can have a very different meanings according to the technical domain and then dictionaries were created by PC based and then load it onto the.
Tangent.
Here you have a step by step description on how the technical dictionaries were built.
You can see that there were EPO and the National Patent Office were involved.
It was quite quite a lot of work and actually we think that additional the technical dictionaries are still a valuable deliverable person.
So in the meantime, what has happened in 2008 the two pairs were started, were completed and put into production translation English, Spanish, Spanish, English and German English, English, German.
Later on we implemented French and Italian in the same way, however, with less satisfactory results.
As a matter of fact.
As you can see, we have implemented them, but the work is.
We don't consider it completed and we're still working working on it.
In the mean time, in the 1st of July 2008, an agreement entered into force the European Patent Office was to carry out national searches for the Italian Patent Office.
So we had a commitment to deliver.
So waiting to certain deadlines?
A service based actually on machine translation because the agreement for so that only the claims would be humanly translated and the description could be translated automatically.
Now you can imagine how it is important, how important it is that that description has certain quality in order to carry out this prior art search.
So, um.
This brought us actually recently to select statistical machine translation for Italian, which is language Weaver.
The decision was taken on the basis of the fact that even untrained language Weaver was delivering a better translation than the original one, with dictionaries.
So in the mean time we had also started.
Of course, our aim was to create a implementation for as many languages as possible.
We started also spending and sorry Swedish and Portuguese, but the results were also not particularly satisfactory and therefore we have these two implementations on hold.
Here I thought it would be.
It would be interesting to add some figures on what how many sentences were extracted and aligned and and also some evaluation through the blue score.
So how are we so?
This is available to the users.
One is through his Pacnet.
Here you have the website and one is internally to the PEO examiners via epoch, which is the search tool.
Here there are some screenshots from his past net so that you can see where the translation is is available.
The translation is available for the abstract.
You can see it here.
It's also available for the description and the claims.
Perfect here you have.
We are in the description field and the translation this text button is also available.
Once that you press.

The bottom you will be prompted to the selection of which language you target language you want the translation into, and this is the screenshot on the second, the second one with the translation into Spanish.
This these are the user numbers, usage numbers of the two directions for each language in the time between January and April 2010.

So for some, for some languages that the figure is very low, like from Spanish to English and from Italian to English, just because we have actually a low number of documents available in in full text in the in Spanish and Italian.
But as you can see otherwise, the numbers are quite high.
Here is.
Also, the pie showing the origins of the request.

And now what happened we it was very clear for us that we have reached the technical limits of the current approach, and we decided that it was not possible to go on in implementations in the same way, and therefore we have drafted.
A new Corporation program cooperation program.
Because it is something that we want to implement it together with the Member States of the people who have the same interests.
They also have the interest to defend the national language is to protect them and to continue to use them.
Also at working level.
So what we want is a system which is tailor made for patterns and that is able to.
Or many systems of course, that so that we can have translations into and from all Member States languages.
So also the less resource languages that we have seen.
Sure.
What do we have today?
Today we have English as private language.
But what we want tomorrow is to have all three official languages as Private Lang.
Edges.
And then our draft is under examination of the Administrative Council.
We plan to have a reply or the green light, the official green light in October 2010.
After that, we can proceed with our plan to collect corpora and then integrate it into services and eventually into patent information tools and other similar tools.
For all, this will, of course we want to work with the Member States and at the moment we are also in working in collaboration with you consortium.
The last slide is indeed a list of the points which are so important for us and that we want to have addressed in our in our program and we look for partners who can satisfy these requirements.
That is, quality requirements, flexibility, requirements offer language.
Often requirements, of course, because at the end of the day, it was clear that we could not.
Offer the same solution for all languages and actually ideally we can use several solutions for the same language pairs so that the users can only have the best results and use them.
Thank you very much.
Thank you very much.
Please rates and questions question.
Charlie.
You mentioned a couple of times that you selected systems according to Angle, feelings or something that I didn't understand.
How is your performance evaluation for selecting, for instance, Language River as the SMT for your kisses?
The world tests done on technical and non technical texts and there was, let's say evaluation was carried out partly based on the blue score and partly based on human evaluation by the examiners.
Cute.
So I was wondering.
Essentially one single institution.
What kind of cheese is your budget for language technologies?
This is a very tricky question becausw.
I can tell you what we plan to spend in our Department, but this is by no means the whole budget, so we have forecasted.
At least again, this is the only.
It will be valid if they administer the Council approves it.
However we have envisaged.
A program of five years which will be around 800,000 per year, all included.
I mean, we're talking about corpora, collection, extraction and and human resources necessary to manage this.
Questioning here.
How to save?
Officials.
What is the relationship between the Russian translation of the medication condition and human translator in your office?
Anne this I'm sure that there is.
There is a.
For instance, I know that the the system they use trados as a system and as an aid for translation.
But as I said.
We are concerned more with providing pattern translation to the public, so this is more of an internal organization matter.
OK, one more question too.
The notion of translating tickets would seem to be something which is very domain specific.
Is this something which is reflected in the way you are setting up door systems?
Will have to be.
OK.
Requires VPN virus that claims to be translated into French German.
You mentioned that language Weaver untrained acepte this better than the rule base, but it wasn't really untrained is you have a huge corpora of all translated claims to be a sentence.
Is that correct?
I was referring to Italian.
We are using language labor only for Italian.
French and German training to claim claims translated.
Maybe some experts can get replied on this.
This is your answer.
OK, thank you again between safe we have to go.
